content: Salmonella Typhimurium is a major food-borne pathogen that can contaminate eggs, although Salmonella Enteritidis remains the dominant serovar in most regions. This review summarizes existing literature on Salmonella Typhimurium infection in laying hens and eggs, highlighting comparisons with other serovars and identifying key knowledge gaps.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonella in chicken eggs?
What are the symptoms of salmonella infection in hens?
How does salmonella typhimurium contaminate eggs?
What is the most common salmonella serovar in most regions?
What are the key differences between salmonella typhimurium and enteritidis?
What antibiotics are effective against salmonella typhimurium in poultry?
What is the role of the gut-associated lymphoid tissue in salmonella typhimurium infection?

metadata.title: Overview of Salmonella Typhimurium infection in laying hens

content: Field studies indicate that Salmonella Typhimurium is occasionally detected in the environments of laying flocks but is rarely isolated from ovarian tissue of hens. This suggests that natural reproductive tract colonization by this serovar is uncommon under field conditions.

hypothetical_questions: Does Salmonella Typhimurium infect hens naturally?
What is the common serovar of Salmonella found in laying flocks?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium be isolated from ovarian tissue of hens?
How common is Salmonella Typhimurium infection in laying flocks?
What is the pathology of Salmonella Typhimurium in laying hens?
Is Salmonella Typhimurium a zoonotic pathogen in poultry?
What is the treatment for Salmonella Typhimurium infection in hens?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium be detected in the environment of laying flocks?
Is Salmonella Typhimurium a common cause of reproductive tract colonization in hens?

metadata.title: Natural occurrence of Salmonella Typhimurium in laying flocks

content: Intravenous inoculation studies show that Salmonella Enteritidis often causes more prolonged bacteraemia and higher recovery from reproductive tissues than Salmonella Typhimurium. However, at very high doses, both serovars can invade organs and contaminate eggs under experimental conditions.

hypothetical_questions: What happens when chickens get Salmonella Typhimurium?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium affect chicken reproductive tissues?
What is the difference between Salmonella Typhimurium and Salmonella Enteritidis in chickens?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium contaminate chicken eggs?
What is the effect of high doses of Salmonella Typhimurium on chicken organs?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium cause bacteraemia in chickens?
What is the pathology of Salmonella Typhimurium infection in poultry?
Is ciprofloxacin effective against Salmonella Typhimurium in chickens?
What is the duration of bacteraemia caused by Salmonella Typhimurium in chickens?

metadata.title: Intravenous experimental infection with Salmonella Typhimurium

content: Oral inoculation experiments demonstrate inconsistent relationships between dose, tissue invasion, and egg contamination. High oral doses of Salmonella Typhimurium frequently lead to faecal shedding and tissue invasion without consistent contamination of eggs.

hypothetical_questions: What happens when chickens eat Salmonella Typhimurium?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium affect chicken eggs?
What are the symptoms of Salmonella Typhimurium infection in chickens?
Can chickens get sick from eating Salmonella Typhimurium?
What is the relationship between oral dose and tissue invasion in Salmonella Typhimurium infection?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium cause faecal shedding in chickens?
What is the role of tissue invasion in Salmonella Typhimurium egg contamination?
Is there a correlation between oral dose and egg contamination in Salmonella Typhimurium infection?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium be transmitted through oral inoculation?
What is the effect of high oral doses of Salmonella Typhimurium on chicken health?

metadata.title: Oral infection and dose effects of Salmonella Typhimurium

content: Alternative infection routes such as vaginal and aerosol exposure can result in systemic infection and egg contamination by Salmonella Typhimurium. Aerosol exposure has been shown to produce higher rates of internal egg contamination than oral inoculation in some experimental models.

hypothetical_questions: What are the alternative routes of Salmonella Typhimurium infection?
What happens when chickens are exposed to Salmonella Typhimurium through the air?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium infect chickens through vaginal exposure?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium contaminate eggs in chickens?
What is the effect of aerosol exposure on internal egg contamination in chickens?

What is the difference between oral and aerosol inoculation of Salmonella Typhimurium in chickens?
What are the risks of Salmonella Typhimurium infection in chickens through vaginal exposure?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium be transmitted to chickens through the air?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium affect egg production in chickens?

metadata.title: Alternative infection routes of Salmonella Typhimurium

content: In vitro studies comparing Salmonella Typhimurium and Salmonella Enteritidis show conflicting results regarding survival in egg albumen, adhesion to reproductive tissues, and macrophage interactions. These findings suggest that regulatory mechanisms may play a larger role than gene presence alone.

hypothetical_questions: What happens when Salmonella Typhimurium is in egg albumen?
Why do some studies show Salmonella Typhimurium can survive in egg albumen?
What's the difference in adhesion to reproductive tissues between Salmonella Typhimurium and Salmonella Enteritidis?
How do macrophages interact with Salmonella Typhimurium in the reproductive system?
What regulatory mechanisms affect Salmonella Typhimurium survival in egg albumen?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium infect reproductive tissues in poultry?
What's the role of gene presence in Salmonella Typhimurium survival in egg albumen?
Are there any specific drugs that can treat Salmonella Typhimurium infections in poultry?
What's the pathogenesis of Salmonella Typhimurium in poultry reproductive systems?

metadata.title: In vitro comparison of Salmonella Typhimurium and Enteritidis

content: Salmonella Typhimurium is more frequently associated with external contamination of eggs than internal contamination. When internal contamination occurs, it is generally at a lower frequency compared with Salmonella Enteritidis.

hypothetical_questions: What causes Salmonella Typhimurium in eggs?
Is Salmonella Typhimurium more likely to be on the outside of eggs?
How often is Salmonella Typhimurium inside eggs compared to Salmonella Enteritidis?

What is the relative frequency of internal Salmonella Typhimurium contamination?
Can Salmonella Typhimurium be transmitted through contact with contaminated eggs?
How does Salmonella Typhimurium compare to Salmonella Enteritidis in terms of egg contamination?

metadata.title: Egg contamination by Salmonella Typhimurium

content: Infections with Salmonella Typhimurium in laying flocks tend to be less persistent than those caused by Salmonella Enteritidis. Environmental reservoirs such as rodents play a smaller role in sustaining Salmonella Typhimurium infections.

hypothetical_questions: What happens if a flock gets Salmonella Typhimurium?
How long do Salmonella Typhimurium infections last in a laying flock?
What's the difference between Salmonella Typhimurium and Salmonella Enteritidis in chickens?
Can rodents carry Salmonella Typhimurium in a chicken farm?
What's the role of environmental reservoirs in Salmonella Typhimurium infections?

What's the significance of Salmonella Typhimurium persistence in poultry flocks?
Salmonella Typhimurium vs Salmonella Enteritidis: What's the main difference?
Salmonella Typhimurium flock persistence: What are the key factors?

metadata.title: Persistence of Salmonella Typhimurium in laying flocks

content: Prevention of Salmonella Typhimurium infection in laying hens relies primarily on strict biosecurity and hygiene measures. These include cleaning and disinfection of housing, control of rodents, and prevention of contamination of feed and water to limit introduction and spread within flocks.

hypothetical_questions: What can I do to stop Salmonella Typhimurium in my chickens?
How do I prevent Salmonella Typhimurium from spreading in my flock?
What are the main ways to keep Salmonella Typhimurium out of my chicken coop?

What are the main hygiene measures for preventing Salmonella Typhimurium in chickens?
Can you explain the importance of rodent control in preventing Salmonella Typhimurium?

metadata.title: Biosecurity measures for preventing Salmonella Typhimurium infection

content: Although Salmonella Typhimurium is capable of contaminating eggs, its role is currently less significant than Salmonella Enteritidis. The review highlights inconsistent findings across studies and emphasizes the need for long-term natural infection research.

hypothetical_questions: What role does Salmonella Typhimurium play in contaminating eggs?
Is Salmonella Typhimurium more significant than Salmonella Enteritidis in egg contamination?

Is Salmonella Typhimurium a significant cause of egg contamination?

metadata.title: Conclusions on Salmonella Typhimurium infection in laying hens

content: Non-typhoidal Salmonella is a zoonotic pathogen associated with gastroenteritis in humans. This study investigated asymptomatic colonization of non-typhoidal Salmonella in backyard chickens, chicken farmers, and unexposed individuals in the Mekong Delta of Vietnam to assess the impact of occupational exposure.

hypothetical_questions: What causes Salmonella in backyard chickens?
Is Salmonella a zoonotic pathogen?
What are the symptoms of Salmonella in humans?
Can non-typhoidal Salmonella be asymptomatic in chickens?
What is the impact of occupational exposure to Salmonella?

Is ciprofloxacin effective against non-typhoidal Salmonella in chickens?
What is the role of the Mekong Delta in Salmonella transmission?
Are unexposed individuals at risk of Salmonella colonization?
Can non-typhoidal Salmonella cause gastroenteritis in humans?

metadata.title: Overview of non-typhoidal Salmonella colonization in Vietnam

content: The study examined 204 backyard chicken farms, 204 chicken farmers, and 306 individuals not exposed to poultry farming in the Mekong Delta of Vietnam. Farms were categorized into household-size and small-size operations, and human participants were age- and sex-matched.

hypothetical_questions: What farms were studied in Vietnam?
What type of farms were categorized in the study?
Are backyard chicken farms safe for humans?
What human participants were matched in the study?
What is the pathology of avian influenza in chickens?
What is the treatment for Newcastle disease in poultry?
What is the difference between household-size and small-size chicken farms?
What are the risk factors for zoonotic diseases in poultry farming?
Chicken farmers in Vietnam what drugs are used to treat fowl pox?
Avian diseases in Mekong Delta what is the common symptom?

metadata.title: Study design and population sampling

content: Non-typhoidal Salmonella colonization was detected in 45.6% of chicken farms, 4.4% of chicken farmers, and 2.6% of unexposed individuals. Farmers showed a higher prevalence of colonization compared with rural and urban individuals not exposed to chickens.

what is the seroprevalence of non-typhoidal Salmonella in chicken farmers?

metadata.title: Prevalence of non-typhoidal Salmonella colonization

content: A total of 28 non-typhoidal Salmonella serovars were identified. Salmonella Weltevreden was the predominant serovar in both chickens and humans, while Salmonella Enteritidis and Salmonella Typhimurium were detected only in chicken farms.

hypothetical_questions: What are the common Salmonella serovars in chickens?

Can Salmonella Enteritidis and Typhimurium be transmitted to humans?
What is the prevalence of Salmonella serovars in chicken farms?

metadata.title: Serovar distribution of non-typhoidal Salmonella

content: Non-typhoidal Salmonella isolates from chickens and humans showed resistance to several antimicrobials, including tetracycline, chloramphenicol, sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, and ampicillin. Multidrug resistance was observed in 27.4% of chicken isolates.

metadata.title: Antimicrobial resistance patterns of non-typhoidal Salmonella

content: Non-typhoidal Salmonella was detected in both chickens and farmers on a small number of farms. In one instance, identical serovars and resistance patterns were observed in chickens and their farmer, suggesting possible transmission between animals and humans.

Can chickens give Salmonella to humans?

metadata.title: Potential transmission of non-typhoidal Salmonella

content: The study was limited by its cross-sectional design and the small number of human non-typhoidal Salmonella isolates, which reduced the ability to demonstrate direct transmission dynamics between chickens and humans.

metadata.title: Study limitations in assessing NTS transmission

content: The study demonstrates a high prevalence of non-typhoidal Salmonella colonization in backyard chicken farms and a higher colonization rate among exposed farmers compared with unexposed individuals. These findings highlight the public health relevance of poultry-associated Salmonella in Vietnam.

metadata.title: Public health implications of non-typhoidal Salmonella in Vietnam

content: Salmonella is a major foodborne pathogen and a leading cause of hospitalization and death associated with foodborne illnesses worldwide. Poultry products are among the primary sources of non-typhoidal salmonellosis in humans, with contamination often originating at the pre-harvest stage through fecal–oral transmission within flocks.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonella in chickens?
How does salmonella get into chicken meat?
What are the risks of eating chicken contaminated with salmonella?
What can farmers do to prevent salmonella in their flocks?
What are the common symptoms of salmonella in humans?
What is the role of fecal-oral transmission in salmonella outbreaks?
How does non-typhoidal salmonellosis affect the human body?
What are some common antibiotics used to treat salmonella infections in humans?

metadata.title: Overview of Salmonella as a foodborne pathogen in poultry

content: Control of Salmonella in poultry production increasingly relies on non-antibiotic pre-harvest interventions, including probiotics, prebiotics, organic acids, essential oils, bacteriophages, vaccines, and combinations of these strategies. These approaches aim to reduce intestinal colonization and subsequent contamination during processing.

hypothetical_questions: What can I use instead of antibiotics to control Salmonella in chickens?
What are some non-antibiotic ways to prevent Salmonella in poultry?
How do I reduce Salmonella contamination in my chicken farm?
What are some natural ways to control Salmonella in poultry?
What are the effects of probiotics on Salmonella colonization in poultry?
What is the role of bacteriophages in controlling Salmonella in poultry production?
How do prebiotics and organic acids work together to control Salmonella in poultry?
What are the benefits of using essential oils to control Salmonella in poultry?

metadata.title: Pre-harvest strategies to control Salmonella in poultry

content: A random-effects meta-analysis of 97 studies demonstrated that non-antibiotic pre-harvest interventions significantly reduced Salmonella populations in meat-type poultry, with an overall standardized mean difference (SMD) of −1.58. This indicates a substantial reduction in intestinal Salmonella load compared with untreated controls.

hypothetical_questions: What reduces Salmonella in poultry?
How do non-antibiotic interventions affect Salmonella in meat-type poultry?
What is the overall effect of non-antibiotic pre-harvest interventions on Salmonella?
Does Salmonella decrease in poultry with non-antibiotic treatments?
What is the mean difference in Salmonella reduction with non-antibiotic interventions?

metadata.title: Overall efficacy of non-antibiotic interventions against Salmonella

content: Vaccination was identified as one of the most effective pre-harvest interventions for reducing Salmonella colonization in poultry. Meta-analysis results showed a strong reduction effect with a standardized mean difference of −2.21, indicating significant potential for controlling both horizontal and vertical transmission within flocks.

hypothetical_questions: What's the best way to stop salmonella in chickens?
How does vaccination help with salmonella in poultry?
What's the effect of vaccination on salmonella in flocks?
Does vaccination really work for salmonella in chickens?
What's the pathology of salmonella in poultry?
How does vaccination impact the transmission of salmonella in flocks?
What's the role of vaccination in controlling vertical transmission of salmonella?
What's the standardized mean difference of vaccination effect on salmonella?

metadata.title: Efficacy of vaccination against Salmonella in poultry

content: Combination strategies involving multiple non-antibiotic interventions showed the greatest reduction in Salmonella populations in poultry. These combined approaches achieved the highest effect size (SMD = −2.34), supporting the concept of a multi-hurdle strategy for effective pre-harvest Salmonella control.

hypothetical_questions: Is using multiple non-antibiotic methods best for reducing Salmonella in chickens?
What are the most effective methods to control Salmonella in poultry farms?
Can a combination of non-antibiotic interventions really reduce Salmonella populations?
What is the best strategy to control Salmonella in poultry before they are harvested?
What is the effect size of using multiple non-antibiotic interventions to control Salmonella?
Can a multi-hurdle approach be effective in controlling Salmonella in poultry?
What are the combined approaches that showed the greatest reduction in Salmonella populations?
Is a multi-hurdle strategy the best way to control Salmonella in poultry?
What is the significance of using a combination of non-antibiotic interventions to control Salmonella?
Can the use of multiple non-antibiotic interventions effectively reduce Salmonella populations in poultry?

metadata.title: Effectiveness of combined interventions against Salmonella

content: Salmonella colonization in poultry is strongly influenced by host immune responses. Both innate and adaptive immunity play key roles in limiting intestinal colonization and systemic spread, making immune-based interventions central to Salmonella control strategies.

hypothetical_questions: What causes Salmonella in chickens?
How does the immune system fight Salmonella in poultry?
What are the main factors that influence Salmonella colonization in poultry?
Can you explain how Salmonella affects the immune system of birds?
What is the role of innate immunity in controlling Salmonella in poultry?
How do adaptive immune responses help prevent Salmonella spread in chickens?

Can you describe the relationship between Salmonella and the host immune response?
What is the impact of Salmonella on the gut-associated lymphoid tissue of poultry?

metadata.title: Role of host immunity in controlling Salmonella infection

content: Innate immune defenses such as gut-associated lymphoid tissue, macrophages, heterophils, and antimicrobial peptides form the first line of defense against Salmonella in poultry. These mechanisms restrict early colonization but are often insufficient to eliminate infection completely.

hypothetical_questions: What happens when chickens get salmonella?
How do chickens fight salmonella infection?
What stops salmonella from spreading in chickens?
Can chickens recover from salmonella infection?
What role do macrophages play in salmonella immunity?
How do antimicrobial peptides help against salmonella in poultry?
What is the first line of defense against salmonella in chickens?
What are the main immune mechanisms against salmonella in poultry?

metadata.title: Innate immune responses to Salmonella in poultry

content: Adaptive immune responses, including Salmonella-specific T-cell responses and antibody production, are critical for long-term control of infection. Secretory IgA contributes to reduced intestinal colonization, while cell-mediated immunity is essential for clearance of intracellular Salmonella.

hypothetical_questions: What causes long-term Salmonella infection?
Does Salmonella affect the chicken's immune system?
What is the role of IgA in Salmonella infection?
Can cell-mediated immunity clear Salmonella from the body?
How does the immune system respond to Salmonella?
What is the difference between humoral and cell-mediated immunity in Salmonella?
Is Salmonella-specific T-cell response essential for infection control?
What is the effect of Salmonella on the chicken's gut?
Can antibiotics treat Salmonella infection in poultry?
Does Salmonella trigger an adaptive immune response?

metadata.title: Adaptive immune mechanisms against Salmonella

content: Several vaccine types are used to control Salmonella in poultry, including live attenuated vaccines, inactivated vaccines, and subunit vaccines. Live attenuated vaccines generally induce stronger cellular and mucosal immune responses compared with inactivated formulations.

hypothetical_questions: What vaccines are used to control Salmonella in poultry?
What is the difference between live and inactivated Salmonella vaccines?
What are the benefits of live attenuated vaccines for Salmonella?
What type of immune response do live attenuated vaccines induce?

metadata.title: Types of vaccines used against Salmonella in poultry

content: Vaccination reduces intestinal colonization and fecal shedding of Salmonella, thereby decreasing environmental contamination and transmission within poultry flocks. Vaccine-induced immunity is particularly effective when combined with good biosecurity practices.

hypothetical_questions: What does vaccination do to Salmonella in chickens?
How does vaccination help with Salmonella in poultry?
Can vaccination stop Salmonella from spreading in the coop?
What are the benefits of vaccinating against Salmonella in birds?
What is the effect of vaccination on Salmonella shedding in poultry?
How does vaccination reduce Salmonella transmission in flocks?
What is the role of biosecurity in Salmonella vaccination?
What are the mechanisms of Salmonella vaccine-induced immunity?
What is the relationship between Salmonella vaccination and fecal shedding?
Does Salmonella vaccination reduce environmental contamination?

metadata.title: Effect of vaccination on Salmonella shedding

content: Despite their effectiveness, Salmonella vaccines have limitations, including serovar specificity, incomplete protection, and variable efficacy under field conditions. Vaccination alone is insufficient and must be integrated with other control measures.

hypothetical_questions: What are the problems with Salmonella vaccines?
What are the limitations of Salmonella vaccines?

metadata.title: Limitations of vaccination for Salmonella control

content: Optimal control of Salmonella in poultry requires integration of vaccination with biosecurity, hygiene, and management practices. A combined approach enhances the effectiveness of immune-based strategies and reduces the risk of Salmonella persistence in production systems.

hypothetical_questions: What's the best way to control Salmonella in chickens?
How can I prevent Salmonella from spreading on my farm?
What are the key factors in reducing Salmonella persistence in poultry?

What are the key immune-based strategies for controlling Salmonella in poultry?

metadata.title: Integrated vaccine and biosecurity approach for Salmonella control

content: Future Salmonella control strategies should focus on improving vaccine design, enhancing mucosal immunity, and combining immunological interventions with management practices to achieve sustainable reductions in Salmonella prevalence in poultry production.

hypothetical_questions: What's the best way to control Salmonella in poultry?
How can we improve vaccine design for Salmonella?
What's the role of mucosal immunity in Salmonella control?

What are some potential future directions for Salmonella control in poultry?

metadata.title: Future directions for immune-based Salmonella control

content: Salmonella contamination in poultry remains a major public health concern, requiring control measures that span the entire poultry production continuum. A multi-hurdle approach integrates multiple pre-harvest and post-harvest interventions to reduce Salmonella prevalence more effectively than single control strategies.

hypothetical_questions: What can I do to stop Salmonella in my chicken farm?
How do I prevent Salmonella in my poultry?

How does the multi-hurdle approach compare to single control strategies for Salmonella?

metadata.title: Overview of multi-hurdle control of Salmonella in poultry

content: Salmonella enterica comprises over 2500 serotypes with varying host adaptation, virulence, and persistence. Only a subset of serotypes, including Enteritidis, Typhimurium, Infantis, and Heidelberg, are commonly associated with poultry and human illness, complicating control efforts.

hypothetical_questions: Is Salmonella enterica a simple disease?
What are the common serotypes of Salmonella in poultry?

What is the mechanism of persistence of Salmonella enterica in poultry?

metadata.title: Complexity and serovar diversity of Salmonella

content: Salmonella can be introduced into poultry production through contaminated feed, hatcheries, water, equipment, and personnel. Vertical transmission from breeder flocks and horizontal transmission among birds contribute to persistence, while cross-contamination occurs during processing stages such as evisceration and chilling.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonella in poultry farms?
How do salmonella bacteria spread in poultry?
Can salmonella be passed from breeder flocks to chicks?

metadata.title: Transmission routes of Salmonella along poultry production continuum

content: Pre-harvest control strategies include feed-based interventions such as probiotics, prebiotics, phytobiotics, and postbiotics. These approaches aim to promote competitive exclusion in the gut and reduce Salmonella colonization, though efficacy varies among serotypes and formulations.

hypothetical_questions: What can I feed my chickens to prevent Salmonella?

metadata.title: Feed-based pre-harvest interventions against Salmonella

content: Vaccination and biosecurity are among the most effective pre-harvest measures to control Salmonella. Live attenuated and inactivated vaccines reduce intestinal colonization and shedding, while biosecurity practices such as rodent control, litter management, and sanitation limit pathogen introduction and spread.

hypothetical_questions: What's the best way to stop Salmonella in chickens?

metadata.title: Vaccination and biosecurity for pre-harvest Salmonella control

content: Post-harvest Salmonella control relies on HACCP programs, good manufacturing practices, and biomapping to identify contamination hotspots. Critical processing steps such as scalding, defeathering, and evisceration are key points where targeted interventions can reduce bacterial loads.

metadata.title: Post-harvest Salmonella control using HACCP and biomapping

content: Chemical antimicrobials such as peracetic acid, chlorine-based compounds, and quaternary ammonium compounds are widely used during poultry processing. Peracetic acid has demonstrated superior efficacy in reducing Salmonella compared with chlorine, particularly during post-chill treatments.

metadata.title: Antimicrobial and sanitation strategies for Salmonella reduction

content: Effective Salmonella control requires a multi-hurdle approach aligned with a One Health perspective, integrating farm-level management, processing interventions, surveillance, and regulatory frameworks. Combining strategies provides synergistic effects and reduces the risk of Salmonella persistence.

metadata.title: Multi-hurdle Salmonella control within a One Health framework

content: Future Salmonella control efforts should focus on optimizing combinations of interventions, evaluating cost–benefit trade-offs, and incorporating emerging technologies such as bacteriophages, genomics, and microbiome-based approaches to enhance food safety.

metadata.title: Future directions for multi-hurdle Salmonella control

content: Salmonella enterica serovar Infantis is an emerging non-typhoidal Salmonella serovar of major public health concern. Its global prevalence in humans has increased in recent decades, with broiler chickens identified as a primary reservoir and source of foodborne transmission.

hypothetical_questions: What causes Salmonella Infantis in chickens?
Is Salmonella Infantis a common disease in broiler chickens?

metadata.title: Overview of Salmonella Infantis as an emerging zoonotic pathogen

content: Among livestock species, broiler chickens are considered a major source of Salmonella Infantis. Since 2014, this serovar has become the most frequently isolated Salmonella serotype in broilers and broiler meat in several regions, particularly in Europe.

metadata.title: Importance of broiler chickens in Salmonella Infantis epidemiology

content: The study followed PRISMA guidelines and analyzed English-language publications from 1957 to 2023. Eligible studies reported flock-level or individual-level prevalence of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens using environmental or bird-level sampling.

hypothetical_questions: What studies show Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens?
What is the study design for Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens?

metadata.title: Systematic review design for Salmonella Infantis prevalence

content: Meta-analysis of nine eligible studies estimated a pooled flock-level prevalence of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens of 9%, with a wide confidence interval (95% CI: 1–26%) and high between-study heterogeneity (I² = 99%).

hypothetical_questions: What's the rate of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chicken flocks?

Can you explain the between-study heterogeneity of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens?
What is the I² value for the heterogeneity of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens?

metadata.title: Flock-level prevalence of Salmonella Infantis in broilers

content: Only four studies reported individual-level prevalence of Salmonella Infantis in broiler chickens. Due to the limited number of eligible studies, a pooled prevalence estimate at the individual level could not be calculated.

metadata.title: Individual-level prevalence of Salmonella Infantis in broilers

content: Most studies reported high levels of antimicrobial resistance in Salmonella Infantis isolates, frequently involving multidrug-resistant clones. Resistance genes were commonly associated with the pESI megaplasmid, which contributes to persistence and spread within poultry production systems.

What is the relationship between the pESI megaplasmid and persistence of Salmonella Infantis?

metadata.title: Antimicrobial resistance in Salmonella Infantis from broilers

content: Risk factors for Salmonella Infantis persistence in broiler farms include poor litter quality, thinning practices, equipment sharing, and suboptimal biosecurity. Stress-related factors such as high stocking density and feed withdrawal may further increase susceptibility.

metadata.title: Risk factors for Salmonella Infantis persistence in broiler farms

content: Effective control of Salmonella Infantis requires strict biosecurity, continuous monitoring, and targeted interventions. Inactivated vaccines for breeders and layers are available in some regions, while universal vaccines against Salmonella Infantis are still under development.

metadata.title: Control strategies for Salmonella Infantis in poultry production

content: The review highlights the growing importance of Salmonella Infantis in broiler production and its public health relevance. Knowledge gaps remain regarding true geographic distribution, individual-level prevalence, and the long-term effectiveness of control strategies.

metadata.title: Conclusions and research gaps on Salmonella Infantis

content: Salmonellosis in poultry refers to a group of infectious diseases caused by bacteria of the genus Salmonella. These diseases vary in clinical presentation and epidemiology depending on the serotype involved and the age of the affected birds. Salmonellosis in poultry includes host-adapted infections, such as pullorum disease and fowl typhoid, as well as non–host-adapted paratyphoid infections that are widely distributed in poultry populations and are important sources of environmental contamination.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonellosis in chickens?
What are the symptoms of salmonellosis in poultry?
Is salmonellosis contagious to humans?
What are the different types of salmonellosis in poultry?
What is the pathology of pullorum disease in chickens?
What is the treatment for fowl typhoid in poultry?
Which antibiotics are effective against Salmonella in poultry?
What is the role of Salmonella serotypes in poultry diseases?

metadata.title: Overview of salmonellosis in poultry

content: Salmonellosis in poultry is caused by bacteria belonging to the genus Salmonella. Host-adapted serotypes include Salmonella enterica serovar Gallinarum biovar Pullorum, which causes pullorum disease, and Salmonella enterica serovar Gallinarum biovar Gallinarum, which causes fowl typhoid. In addition, numerous non–host-adapted paratyphoid Salmonella serotypes, such as Salmonella Enteritidis and Salmonella Typhimurium, can infect poultry and contribute to fecal shedding and environmental contamination.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonellosis in poultry?
What are the bacteria that cause pullorum disease?
What is the cause of fowl typhoid in poultry?
What are the non-host-adapted Salmonella serotypes that infect poultry?
What are the host-adapted Salmonella serotypes in poultry?
What is the role of Salmonella Enteritidis in poultry disease?
What is the biovar of Salmonella enterica serovar Gallinarum that causes pullorum disease?
What is the pathogenesis of fowl typhoid in poultry?

metadata.title: Causative agents of salmonellosis in poultry

content: Salmonella is commonly transmitted among poultry through the fecal–oral route. Infected birds shed the organism in their feces, leading to contamination of litter, feed, water, and housing environments. This mode of transmission facilitates rapid horizontal spread within flocks, particularly under conditions of poor hygiene and high stocking density.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonella in chickens?
How do chickens get salmonella?
What is the main route of salmonella transmission in poultry?
Is salmonella spread through feces in chickens?
What are the risk factors for salmonella transmission in poultry flocks?
Can salmonella be transmitted through contaminated feed?
What is the role of hygiene in preventing salmonella spread in poultry?
How does high stocking density contribute to salmonella transmission?

metadata.title: Fecal–oral transmission of salmonellosis in poultry

content: Certain Salmonella serotypes, particularly host-adapted strains such as Salmonella Pullorum and Salmonella Gallinarum, can be transmitted vertically from infected breeder hens to their offspring through eggs. Vertical transmission plays a critical role in the persistence of salmonellosis within breeding flocks and contributes to early infection and high mortality in young chicks.

hypothetical_questions: What causes salmonella in chicks?
How do hens pass salmonella to their babies?
What is the main way salmonella spreads in chicken farms?
Can salmonella be passed from mother to child in chickens?
What are the specific Salmonella serotypes that cause vertical transmission in poultry?
How does Salmonella Pullorum affect young chicks?
What is the role of Salmonella Gallinarum in vertical transmission of salmonellosis?
What is the pathogenesis of vertical transmission of salmonellosis in chickens?

metadata.title: Vertical transmission of salmonellosis through eggs

content: Paratyphoid Salmonella infections are most commonly observed in young poultry and may range from subclinical infection to overt disease. Clinically affected birds often show depression, poor growth, weakness, dehydration, and diarrhea. Infected birds can shed large numbers of Salmonella organisms in their feces, contributing to environmental contamination and transmission within flocks.

hypothetical_questions: What causes diarrhea in young chickens?
What are the symptoms of Paratyphoid Salmonella infection in poultry?
How do Salmonella organisms spread within a flock?
What are the common signs of Paratyphoid Salmonella infection in birds?

What are the effects of Salmonella shedding on environmental contamination?
What are the most common clinical signs of Paratyphoid Salmonella infection?
Can Paratyphoid Salmonella infection be asymptomatic in poultry?

metadata.title: Diarrhea associated with paratyphoid salmonellosis

content: Pullorum disease, caused by Salmonella Pullorum, primarily affects young chicks and is characterized by high mortality. Affected birds are anorectic, weak, and lethargic and commonly produce white or whitish fecal material that becomes pasted around the vent area. This distinctive fecal appearance is considered a hallmark clinical sign of pullorum disease.

hypothetical_questions: what causes white poop in chicks?
how to treat pullorum disease in poultry?
what is the hallmark clinical sign of pullorum disease?

metadata.title: White fecal material in pullorum disease

content: In fowl typhoid, clinical signs vary with the age of the affected birds. Young birds may appear weak, anorectic, and depressed and can show white fecal material pasted to the vent area. Older birds are more likely to be pale and dehydrated and may develop diarrhea. Gastrointestinal signs may be present but are not always the dominant feature of the disease.

What are the clinical signs of fowl typhoid in older birds?

Is fowl typhoid more common in young or old birds?
What is the pathology of fowl typhoid in chickens?
What are the symptoms of fowl typhoid in birds with diarrhea?
Is fowl typhoid a zoonotic disease?

metadata.title: Fecal abnormalities in fowl typhoid

content: In laying hens, infection with Salmonella Enteritidis may be associated with gastrointestinal disturbances, including diarrhea and reduced feed consumption. Affected birds may also exhibit decreased egg production while continuing to shed Salmonella organisms in their feces, increasing the risk of environmental contamination.

hypothetical_questions: What causes diarrhea in laying hens?
Symptoms of Salmonella Enteritidis in egg-laying hens?
Can Salmonella Enteritidis infection affect egg production in laying hens?
What are the gastrointestinal symptoms of Salmonella Enteritidis in laying hens?

metadata.title: Digestive signs of Salmonella Enteritidis in layers

content: Salmonella infections in poultry may result in inflammatory changes within the intestinal tract, reflecting bacterial invasion and systemic spread. Intestinal involvement contributes to impaired digestion and altered fecal consistency. In some cases, lesions may also be observed in internal organs such as the liver and spleen, particularly in severe or systemic infections.

metadata.title: Pathological changes associated with salmonellosis

content: Clinical signs of salmonellosis in poultry are variable and may overlap with those of other infectious diseases, particularly those affecting the gastrointestinal system. Because fecal appearance and general clinical signs alone are insufficient for definitive identification, diagnosis relies on isolation and identification of the organism using bacteriologic methods.

How do you diagnose salmonella in poultry?

Is bacteriologic culture the gold standard for diagnosing salmonellosis?

metadata.title: Diagnosis of salmonellosis in poultry

content: In poultry flocks affected by salmonellosis, treatment is generally based on management measures rather than therapeutic intervention. Elimination of infected birds, particularly in breeding flocks, is recommended to reduce the risk of persistent carrier states and ongoing environmental contamination. Isolation and removal of affected birds play a key role in limiting transmission within flocks.

How do you prevent salmonella from becoming a persistent carrier state?

What is the role of isolation in limiting salmonella transmission?
Can you use antibiotics to treat salmonella in poultry?
What is the significance of removing infected birds in breeding flocks?

metadata.title: Culling and isolation as a management strategy for salmonellosis

content: Antimicrobial treatment of salmonellosis in poultry is generally discouraged because it rarely eliminates the organism and may contribute to the development of antimicrobial resistance. Treated birds may continue to shed Salmonella in their feces, resulting in persistent environmental contamination and limited long-term benefit at the flock level.

What are the long-term effects of treating salmonella in poultry with antibiotics?

metadata.title: Limitations of antimicrobial treatment in salmonellosis

content: In certain circumstances, such as clinical salmonellosis in young birds, antimicrobial therapy may be considered under veterinary supervision. In these cases, treatment decisions should be guided by bacterial culture and antimicrobial susceptibility testing due to variability in resistance patterns among Salmonella isolates.

metadata.title: Restricted antimicrobial use in young birds with salmonellosis

content: Prevention of salmonellosis in poultry relies heavily on good hygiene, sanitation, and strict biosecurity measures. These include proper cleaning and disinfection of housing, control of rodent and insect vectors, and prevention of fecal contamination of feed and water. Effective biosecurity reduces the introduction and spread of Salmonella within flocks.

What is the role of biosecurity in preventing salmonella?

metadata.title: Biosecurity measures for preventing salmonellosis

content: Control of salmonellosis in breeding flocks is essential to prevent vertical transmission of the organism to offspring. Monitoring, testing, and removal of infected breeder birds are important strategies to reduce the risk of egg-borne infection and subsequent spread of Salmonella in poultry production systems.
